body.p:
I received yours of 31st ult. last week with
the Occidents and regret to learn from it you had not been quite
well since your return to Phila. I presume however, you
require no one to point out to you the inutility of permitting
yourself to be annoyed because all things go not right. As
for the fictional convention & the doings of our ultra reformers
(permit me to say you attach as I think too much importance
to them. By showing the extreme ugliness of their deformities
if I may so say we can better serve the cause of historical
Judaism than by creating into heroes a few men who have
more philosophy than religion. The talent & activity of these
ultras cannot but be admired, and movement and life
are always better than drowsiness & stagnation. Perhaps
if it were not for the doings of some of these mischievous
demagogues a long Hebrew would fall upon the people
—awaking from which we should find the fabric of Judaism
had so suffered that most laborious efforts persevered
in for many years must be resorted to, to restore it
to its pristine excellence.

I am greatly obliged to you for advertising
my proposals to publish school-books but will not further
avail myself of your kindness for the present because
for the present I abandon the idea of publication.
Templo's Grammar I would have published as I intended

(as I before wrote you) so soon as you had returned; because you
wrote me in October or November “it would not be a killing
thing” & you “would not mind lending a hand so that But,
perhaps I have to thank you that I have not embarked in
a lap to both. Please under the circumstances discontinue
the advertisement.

Now that I see Mende's Sermon, I did not see the no of the Chron? containing it. I don't know
why Wise should ? out so lustily “plagiarism.” An
eulogy of mine of “Vaterland” given before a crowded audience
on Humiliation Day (I sent you a paper did you receive it?)
was inserted almost word for word as the lucubrations
of one of our “head-hitters” a couple of days after. There
was no mistaking it, but I certainly did not think
of calling him to account. Mais apropas des battes—
I am sorry you appearing as a correspondent of the Israelite
you ?. Will you please do me a favor, and let
one know “by return of post” what induced you
to write this. I do not recollect having contributed
anything to the Israelite and will gladly pay 10 cents
to have my memory respected, if I have written and
forgotten. I am anxious to hear from you on this
subject. I would write however for any paper if I
thought I could thereby advance the cause I desire to serve
always provided I was fairly & properly treated.
I will even contribute (when so urged)
to baby publications ? magazines which ?
to spring up but which I guess not more, if as much
as the older ones will flourish. I have not seen
Wises article Hebrew—I must close ?sting you Hebrew
